skill.name: molfeat
skill.description: Molecular featurization for ML (100+ featurizers). ECFP, MACCS, descriptors, pretrained models (ChemBERTa), convert SMILES to features, for QSAR and molecular ML.
skill.summary: Molecular featurization for ML (100+ featurizers). ECFP, MACCS, descriptors, pretrained models (Chem...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown documentation and JSON configuration files describing the molfeat Python library. No network calls, file system access beyond its own directory, environment variable access, or command execution capabilities detected.

content.value_statement: Convert chemical structures into numerical features for machine learning. Access 100+ featurizers including ECFP, MACCS, RDKit descriptors, and pretrained deep learning models like ChemBERTa for QSAR modeling, virtual screening, and drug discovery.
actual_capabilities: Generate molecular fingerprints (ECFP, MACCS, MAP4, Avalon) from SMILES strings
Calculate 2D and 3D molecular descriptors (RDKit, Mordred, CATS pharmacophores)
Use pretrained transformer models (ChemBERTa, ChemGPT, Graphormer) for deep learning embeddings
Build scikit-learn compatible featurization pipelines for batch processing
Combine multiple featurizers and save configurations for reproducibility
Perform similarity searching and virtual screening workflows
limitations: Does not generate or validate chemical structures - requires valid SMILES input
Does not train machine learning models - only generates features for downstream ML
Some featurizers require optional dependencies (DGL for GNNs, transformers for ChemBERTa)
Does not perform molecular dynamics or docking simulations

use_cases.title: Build QSAR prediction models
use_cases.description: Convert molecules to features and train models to predict solubility, toxicity, or binding affinity.

use_cases.title: Screen compound libraries
use_cases.description: Identify similar molecules to known actives using fingerprint similarity and machine learning classifiers.

use_cases.title: Create molecular ML pipelines
use_cases.description: Integrate molecular featurization with scikit-learn or PyTorch for end-to-end cheminformatics workflows.

prompt_templates.title: Basic fingerprint
prompt_templates.prompt: Use molfeat to generate ECFP4 (radius=3, 2048 bits) fingerprints for these SMILES strings and return the feature shapes.

prompt_templates.title: Compare featurizers
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare ECFP, MACCS, and RDKit 2D descriptors for these molecules. Show the dimensionality and compute time for each.

prompt_templates.title: Deep learning embeddings
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the ChemBERTa-77M-MLM model and generate 768-dimensional embeddings for this list of drug-like molecules.

prompt_templates.title: Virtual screening
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a virtual screening pipeline using molfeat fingerprints and a Random Forest classifier to rank this library of 10,000 compounds by predicted activity.

output_examples.input: Generate fingerprints for caffeine, aspirin, and ibuprofen using ECFP4
output: Caffeine (ECFP4): 2048-dimensional vector with top bits at positions 123, 456, 789...
Aspirin (ECFP4): 2048-dimensional vector with top bits at positions 234, 567, 890...
Ibuprofen (ECFP4): 2048-dimensional vector with top bits at positions 345, 678, 901...

best_practices: Use n_jobs=-1 for parallel processing when featurizing large datasets
Set ignore_errors=True when processing datasets that may contain invalid SMILES
Save transformer configurations with to_state_yaml_file() for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Using deep learning models for small datasets where simple fingerprints suffice
Processing molecules one at a time instead of batching for efficiency
Forgetting to install optional dependencies for specific featurizer types

faq.question: Which featurizer should I start with?
faq.answer: ECFP4 is the most popular general-purpose fingerprint. Use MACCS for scaffold hopping and RDKit descriptors for interpretable models.

faq.question: What is the difference between fingerprints and descriptors?
faq.answer: Fingerprints are binary/count vectors representing substructure presence. Descriptors are numerical properties like molecular weight, logP, or TPSA.

faq.question: How do I install support for ChemBERTa models?
faq.answer: Run: pip install molfeat[transformer] This installs the HuggingFace transformers and tokenizers required.

faq.question: Is my molecular data safe?
faq.answer: All featurization happens locally. Molfeat does not transmit molecular data to external servers. Pretrained model weights are downloaded once from HuggingFace.

faq.question: Why are my embeddings returning None?
faq.answer: This usually means invalid SMILES. Enable ignore_errors=True and verbose=True to identify problematic molecules in your dataset.

faq.question: How does molfeat compare to RDKit alone?
faq.answer: Molfeat provides a unified interface to 100+ featurizers including RDKit, plus deep learning models like ChemBERTa that RDKit cannot compute.
